tenant_rights.title: Tenant Rights
tenant_rights.description: Laws protecting tenants from unfair practices

scenarios.applicable_law: Most states require 24-48 hours notice before landlord entry except emergencies
scenarios.rights_summary: You have the right to peaceful enjoyment of your rental property. Landlords cannot enter without proper notice except in emergencies.
actions: Document all unauthorized entries with dates and times
Send written notice to landlord about violation
Check your state's specific notice requirements (typically 24-48 hours)
Contact local tenant rights organization if violations continue
Consider legal action if pattern of harassment established

scenarios.applicable_law: Security deposits must be returned within 14-60 days depending on state, with itemized deductions
scenarios.rights_summary: You have the right to receive your security deposit back within the timeframe specified by your state law, minus legitimate deductions for damages beyond normal wear and tear.
actions: Review your lease agreement for deposit terms
Document the condition of the property with photos when moving out
Send written demand letter to landlord
File complaint with local housing authority
Consider small claims court if deposit exceeds $500

scenarios.applicable_law: Title VII of Civil Rights Act protects against harassment based on protected characteristics
scenarios.rights_summary: You have the right to work in an environment free from harassment based on race, gender, religion, age, disability, or other protected characteristics.
actions: Document all incidents with dates, times, witnesses
Report to HR or supervisor in writing
File complaint with EEOC within 180-300 days
Keep copies of all communications
Consider consulting employment attorney

consumer_protection.title: Consumer Protection
consumer_protection.description: Laws protecting consumers from fraud and unfair practices

scenarios.applicable_law: Federal Trade Commission Act prohibits unfair or deceptive practices in commerce
scenarios.rights_summary: You have the right to receive goods as advertised and to dispute fraudulent charges on your credit card.
actions: Contact your credit card company to dispute charges
File complaint with FTC at reportfraud.ftc.gov
Report to state attorney general's office
Keep all documentation and communications
Consider filing police report for criminal fraud

contracts.title: Contract Disputes
contracts.description: Laws governing contract formation and enforcement

scenarios.applicable_law: Uniform Commercial Code and state contract law govern enforcement of agreements
scenarios.rights_summary: You have the right to receive services as agreed in your contract or seek remedies for breach.
actions: Review contract terms and identify specific breaches
Document all communications and failed performance
Send formal notice of breach
Attempt good faith negotiation
Consider mediation or small claims court
